Many processes of terminal differentiation involve extensive remodeling of the complement of cellular proteins, including the elimination of previously stable polypeptides. During erythroid differentiation, for example, there is a programmed loss of most proteins from the progenitor cell, concomitant with induced expression of a limited number of proteins (1.Rapoport S. The Reticulocyte. CRC Press, Boca Raton. FL1986Google Scholar). The precise mechanismts) by which programmed protein elimination is accomplished during this and other processes of terminal differentiation is unknown. The multienzyme ubiquitin-dependent proteolytic pathway is highly active in reticulocytes (2.Hershko A. Ciechanover A. Heller H. Haas A.L. Rose I.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1982; 77: 1783-1786Google Scholar), and mediates the degradation of hexokinase (3.Magnani M. Stocchi V. Chiarantini L. Serafini G. Dacha M. Fornaini G. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 8327-8333Google Scholar) and mito-chondrial proteins (4.Rapoport S.M. Schewe T. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1986; 864: 471-495Google Scholar) in reticulocyte extracts. These observations suggest that the ubiquitin pathway may function in remodeling of the cellular protein complement during erythroid differentiation. Such a role might be expected to involve modulation of the specificity or global activity of this pathway, which in actively dividing cells carries out turnover of most short-lived proteins (5.Ciechanover A. Finley D. Varshavsky A. Cell. 1984; 37: 57-66Google Scholar, 6.Seufert W. Jentsch S. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 540-543Google Scholar), including certain regulatory proteins (7.Glotzer M. Murray A.W. Kirschner M.W. Nature. 1991; 349: 132-138Google Scholar, 8.Scheffner M. Werness B.A. Huibregste J.M. Levine A.J. Howley P.M. Cell. 1990; 63: 1129-1136Google Scholar, 9.Shanklin J. Jabben M. Vierstra R.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 1987; 84: 359-363Google Scholar). The mechanistic role of ubiquitin in proteolysis is that of a covalent signal for degradation (10.Hershko A. Ciechanover A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 761-808Google Scholar). Ubiquitin-protein conjugates have an isopeptide structure, in which the ubiquitin C terminus (Gly76) is linked to the side chain of an internal Lys residue of the target protein. Degradation, which is carried out by the 26 S proteasome, is particularly efficient when a homopolymeric multiubiquitin chain is elaborated on the target protein Lys residue, via formation of Gly76-Lys48 isopeptide bonds between successive ubiquitins (11.Chau V. Tobias J.W. Bachmair A. Marriott D. Ecker D.J. Gonda D.K. Varshavsky A. Science. 1989; 243: 1576-1583Google Scholar, 12.Gregori L. Poasch M.S. Cousins G. Chau V. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 8354-8357Google Scholar). Ubiquitination is a multistep process (10.Hershko A. Ciechanover A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 761-808Google Scholar, 13.Hershko A. Heller H. Elias S. Ciechanover A. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 8206-8214Google Scholar) which begins with ubiquitin activation through formation of a thiol ester with ubiquitin-activating enzyme (E1). Ubiquitin is next transferred to the activesite thiol of a ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme (E2), and then finally transferred to the target protein. This last step usually involves a ubiquitin-protein ligase (E3). Specificity in ubiquitin-mediated turnover appears to arise mainly in the ubiquitination step, and reflects in part the existence of multiple E2 and E3 enzymes with defined specificities (10.Hershko A. Ciechanover A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 761-808Google Scholar, 14.Jentsch S. Seufert W. Hauser H.P. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1089: 127-139Google Scholar). Currently several types of E3 are known (15.Reiss Y. Hershko A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 3685-3690Google Scholar, 16.Heller H. Hershko A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 6532-6535Google Scholar, 17.Bartel B. Wunning I. Varshavsky A. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 3179-3189Google Scholar, 18.Huibregste J.M. Scheffner M. Howley P.M. Mol. Cell. Bioi. 1993; 13: 775-784Google Scholar), and there are more than 10 members of the conserved E2 protein family in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae and in mammalian cells (14.Jentsch S. Seufert W. Hauser H.P. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1089: 127-139Google Scholar). Certain E2s have well-defined biological roles. Thus in S. cerevisiae, the DBC1, -4, and -5 proteins have overlapping functions in turnover of the bulk of short-lived proteins (6.Seufert W. Jentsch S. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 540-543Google Scholar, 19.Seufert W. McGrath J.P. Jentsch S. EMBO J. 1990; 13: 4535-4541Google Scholar), and RAD6(DBC2) is essential for DNA repair (20.Jentsch S. McGrath J.P. Varshavsky A. Nature. 1987; 329: 131-143Google Scholar). In mammals, a close homolog of DBC5 functions in turnover of p53 (21.Scheffner M. Huibregste J.M. Howley P.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 8797-8801Google Scholar), and probably in other degradation as well. These and other findings have led to the view that individual E2s act on specific intracellular targets, either through direct interaction with these targets, and/or through interaction with specific E3s. However, the physiological roles of many E2s, especially in mammals, remain poorly understood. Prior work on changes in the activities of ubiquitin conjugating components during erythroid differentiation has focused on the terminal maturation of reticulocytes to erythrocytes (2224). Here we report on studies of ubiquitination in murine erythroleukemia (MEL)l cells, which allow access to stages of differentiation between the proerythroblast and very early re1ticulocytes (25.Friend C. Scher W. Holland J.G. Sato T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 1971; 68: 378-382Google Scholar, 26.Parker D. Housman D. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 604-609Google Scholar, 27.Patel V.P. Lodish H.F. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 3105-3118Google Scholar, 28.Volloch V. Housman D. J. Cell Biol. 1982; 93: 390-394Google Scholar). The results bear on the role of the ubiquitin pathway in protein remodeling during erythroid differentiation, and also on the biological roles of specific E2 proteins. Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (with glucose and L-glutamine, without pyruvate and bicarbonate) was from Life Technologies, Inc. FBS (Sigma or Life Technologies, Inc.) was heat-inactivated (50°C, 60 min); the results of preliminary experiments were used to select lots of FBS which effectively supported induction of band 3 protein during differentiation (below). MEL cell clone CD5, selected for ability to differentiate in response to Me2SO, was provided by Dr. V. Patel (Northwestern Univ.). Sterile BSA solution was from Sigma or Boehringer Mannheim. Human foreskin fibronectin was from UBI. Imferon (an iron-dextran formulation) was from Fisons. Other reagents were from Sigma, except where indicated. Experiments were initiated within 2 weeks of thawing frozen cells. Prior to initiating experiments, cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 10% FBS, 4.4 mx sodium bicarbonate, and 0.1 mg/ml each of penicillin and streptomycin, in a humid 37°C incubator (8% CO 2), and cell densities were rigorously maintained between 2 and 9 x 10 5 cells/ml. The standard differentiation protocol employed a stabilizing medium containing: Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium, 4.4 mM bicarbonate, 13% FBS, 4-5% BSA, and 1.8 mM Imferon, pH 7.4 (26.Parker D. Housman D. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 604-609Google Scholar, 27.Patel V.P. Lodish H.F. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 3105-3118Google Scholar, 28.Volloch V. Housman D. J. Cell Biol. 1982; 93: 390-394Google Scholar). One day before beginning an experiment, cells were diluted into a 1:1 (v/v) mixture of standard medium:differentiation medium. After 12-18 h, the cells were pelleted and resuspended in warm differentiation medium. After 12-18 h more, the experiment was initiated by diluting the cells into differentiation medium containing (differentiation) or lacking (control) 1.8% (v/v) Me 2SO, at a final density of 5-7 x 10' cells/ml. After 3 days of growth, cells were pelleted by centrifugation, and resuspended in the same volume of differentiation medium without Me 2SO. (Control cell medium was also changed.) Otherwise cultures were not disturbed until harvest. Growth of MEL cells on a fibronectin matrix can provide certain advantages in studies of differentiation (27.Patel V.P. Lodish H.F. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 3105-3118Google Scholar). In initial experiments comparing cells grown in suspension versus on fibronectin-coated plates, we obtained qualitatively similar results over 96 h in regard to levels of band 3, globin, E2 proteins, and ubiquitin conjugates (culture on fibronectin as described in Ref. 27.Patel V.P. Lodish H.F. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 3105-3118Google Scholar; data not shown). Since fibronectin is expensive and its use offered no special advantages in our studies, most experiments were carried out in suspension culture (above). As expected (26.Parker D. Housman D. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 604-609Google Scholar, 28.Volloch V. Housman D. J. Cell Biol. 1982; 93: 390-394Google Scholar), MEL cells cultured in suspension differentiated efficiently only if BSA was present in the medium. Cells were washed once with cold Hank's balanced salt solution with HEPES (50 mM, pH 7.4) containing 10-20 mg/ml BSA, suspended in Hank's balanced salt solution buffered with HEPES (no BSA), and counted with a hemocytometer. Cells were pelleted, and lysed by vortexing in extraction buffer (70 ILl of buffer/2.5 x 10 6 cells) containing: 5 roM Tris-HCl (24% base, pH 7.6), 5 mM EDTA (pH 7), 5 mM N-ethylmaleimide (or iodoacetamide), 1% (v/v) Nonidet P-40 (U. S. Biochemical Corp.), 0.1% SDS, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 0.25 mM TLCK, 10 ILg/ml each of soybean trypsin inhibitor and leupeptin, and 4 or 8 Murea. (Urea improved the long-term stability of ubiquitin conjugates in the lysate.) After 10 min on ice, the extract was centrifuged in the cold (15,000 x g, 5 min.) The supernatant was stored at -60°C. Occasionally, a two-step extraction procedure (27.Patel V.P. Lodish H.F. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 3105-3118Google Scholar) was used, and gave identical results in blotting experiments. In experiments with cells grown on fibronectin-coated plates, harvesting and lysis were as described (27.Patel V.P. Lodish H.F. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 3105-3118Google Scholar). Undifferentiated MEL cells, 2 X 107, were harvested and washed (above), and suspended in 1 ml of buffer containing: 50 mM Tris-HCl (24% base), 5 mM EDTA, 5 mM N-ethylmaleimide, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 0.25 roM TLCK, and 10 ILg/ml each of soybean trypsin inhibitor and leupeptin. Cells were homogenized with a glass Dounce until >90% lysis had occurred as judged by microscopic examination. The lysate was centrifuged (700 x g, 2 min) to produce a nuclear pellet. The 700 x g supernatant was centrifuged (9,000 x g, 15 min) to produce a crude mitochondrial pellet. The 9,000 x g supernatant was centrifuged (100,000 x g, 60 min) to produce a microsomal/ribosomal pellet. The final supernatant served as the cytosolic fraction. The pellet of each spin was suspended in a volume of lysis buffer equal to the volume of the supernatant from the same spin. Affinity-purified antibodies specific for the conjugated and free forms of ubiquitin (herein termed conjugate and free ubiquitin antibodies, respectively) were prepared as described (22.Haas A.L. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 12464-12473Google Scholar, 29.Haas A.L. Murphy K.E. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 4694-4703Google Scholar). Affinity purified antibodies against yeast RAD6 protein were provided by L. Prakash (University of Texas, Galveston). Other antibodies (below) were raised by immunizing female New Zealand White rabbits (22.Haas A.L. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 12464-12473Google Scholar), and affinity purified (22.Haas A.L. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 12464-12473Google Scholar) using resins specified below. For band 3, we immunized with a synthetic peptide from the C terminus (GLDEYDEVPNPV; Ref. 30.Kopito R.R. Lodish H.F. Nature. 1985; 316: 234-238Google Scholar), coupled to bovine -y-globulin with glutaraldehyde (22.Haas A.L. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 12464-12473Google Scholar). Antibodies were purified on a peptide-Sepharose column (0.8 ILmol of peptide/ml resin) prepared from activated CH-Sepharose 4B (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.). For E2-25K, we immunized with the purified recombinant protein (31.Pickart C.M. Haldeman M.T. Kasperek E.M. Chen Z. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14418-14423Google Scholar), and purified the antibodies on an E2-25KSepharose column (0.7 mg of E2/ml resin). For E2-230K, we immunized with a synthetic peptide (CVSDSGLFFDDSY, below) coupled to keyhole limpet hemocyanin using the heterobifunctional cross-linker m-maleimidobenzoic acid N-hydroxysuccinimide ester (Sigma). Antibodies were purified on a column in which the peptide was bound to Sulfolink resin (Pierce) through its Cys sulfhydryl group (0.25 ILmolof peptide/ml of resin). Affinity eluates were concentrated to ~ 10% of the starting serum volume. E1 and E2 proteins were purified by methods standard in our laboratory (23.Pickart C.M. Vella A.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 12028-12035Google Scholar, 32.Klemperer N.S. Berleth E.S. Pickart C.M. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 6035-6041Google Scholar). Isopeptidase T was purified to 90% homogeneity from bovine erythrocytes (33.Hadari T. Warms J.V.B. Rose I.A. Hershko A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 719-727Google Scholar). Erythrocyte ghosts were prepared from murine erythrocytes by hypotonic lysis (34.Steck T. Fairbanks G. Wallach D.H.F. Biochemistry. 1971; 10: 2617-2624Google Scholar). A standard of conjugated ubiquitin for slotblotting was prepared using rabbit reticulocyte fraction II (22.Haas A.L. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 12464-12473Google Scholar) and quenched in lysis buffer containing Nonidet P-40 and 8 Murea (above). The multiubiquitin chain standard contained equal amounts (ILg) of purified ubiquitin monomer, dimer, trimer, tetramer, and hexamer (31.Pickart C.M. Haldeman M.T. Kasperek E.M. Chen Z. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14418-14423Google Scholar). Digestion of proteins, resolution of peptides, and sequencing were carried out at the Harvard Microchemistry Facility. A, purified rabbit reticulocyte E2-230K (32.Klemperer N.S. Berleth E.S. Pickart C.M. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 6035-6041Google Scholar), 20 ILg, was run on a preparative SDS-PAGE gel and blotted onto nitrocellulose. The E2230K band was located by staining with Ponceau S, excised from the blot, and the protein digested with trypsin in situ. Tryptic peptides were separated by reverse-phase high performance liquid chromatography, and a well resolved peptide was sequenced (VSDSGLFFDDSY). B, purified reduced and carboxymethylated rabbit reticulocyte E2-35K, ~50 ILg, was digested in solution with endoproteinase Lys-C, and peptides were resolved by reverse-phase high performance liquid chromatography. A well resolved peptide was sequenced (“Results”). Unless otherwise stated, SDS-PAGE was performed in 0.75-mm thick mini gels (35.Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Google Scholar). Blotting (onto Immobilon, Millipore) and immunostaining were carried out as described (22.Haas A.L. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 12464-12473Google Scholar), except that the washing buffer also contained 0.5% (v/v) Tween 20. 125I-Protein A, used at 1 ILCi/ml, was from ICN or Amersham (Bolton-Hunter labeled, affinity-purified). Immunostained bands were detected by autoradiography (22.Haas A.L. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 12464-12473Google Scholar). Dilutions of primary antibodies were: anti-RAD6 (1:1000; 13.5% gels); anti-band 3 (1:150; 8% gels); anti-E2-25K (1:2000; 12.5% gels); anti-conjugate (1:1500; 12.5 or 13.5% gels); anti-E2-230K (1:1000; 8% gels). For purposes of quantitation, cell extracts were run on gels together with amounts of purified E2 bracketing the physiological [E2] range. Autoradiographs were usually analyzed by densitometry (23.Pickart C.M. Vella A.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 12028-12035Google Scholar, 36.Pickart C.M. Summers R.G. Shim H. Kasperek E.M. Dev. Growth Differ. 1991; 33: 587-598Google Scholar); cellular E2 levels were estimated by comparison to the standard curve. In some cases, immunostained bands were excised from the blot (following autoradiography) and counted directly; here also, unknowns were quantitated by comparison to the standard curve. Levels of band 3 protein were quantitated using a standard of murine erythrocyte ghosts. Coomassie-stained gels were analyzed by direct densitometry, using loads in the linear range of signal. Slot-blotting was carried out as described (22.Haas A.L. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 12464-12473Google Scholar). Standards containing 10-500 fmol of conjugated ubiquitin in 100 ILl ofTS buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.6, 0.15 M NaCI) were applied to Immobilon in triplicate, together with diluted lysates from MEL cells (l03 to 10 5 cell equivalents in 100 ILl of TS). Slot-blots were immunostained using conjugate antibodies and 125I_protein A (above); autoradiographs were analyzed by densitometry (23,36). Solution-phase radioimmunoassay (22.Haas A.L. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 12464-12473Google Scholar) of free ubiquitin was carried out using free ubiquitin antibodies (29.Haas A.L. Murphy K.E. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 4694-4703Google Scholar). This was carried out by the method of O'Farrell (37.O'Farrell P.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1975; 250: 4007-4021Google Scholar) in tubes of 1.5 mm x 5.5 em, using the Bio-Rad Mini-Protean isoelectric focusing apparatus according to the manufacturer's instructions, with pH 3-10 ampholines (Bio-Rad). After loading, tube gels were focused for 10 min at 500 V, followed by 3.5 h at 750 V. IEF gels were either equilibrated with SDS-PAGE sample buffer (35.Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Google Scholar) immediately, or frozen at -60°C until use. Second dimension SDSPAGE was carried out using I-rnm thick mini gels (12.5% acrylamide). Partial Purification of Multiubiquitin Chains from MEL Cells-Undifferentiated MEL cells, 8 x 10 7 , were lysed in 2 ml of buffer containing 1% Nonidet P-40 and 8 M urea (above). The lysate was clarified by centrifugation and applied to 1 ml of Q-Sepharose (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) equilibrated with 50 mxt Tris-H CI (24% base, pH 7.6). A 5-ml wash with this buffer was combined with the unbound fraction; the pooled material was adjusted to pH 4.5 with 2 N acetic acid and applied to 1 ml of S-Sepharose equilibrated with 50 mxi ammonium acetate , pH 4.5. The loaded column was washed with 10 ml of the same buffer, and then eluted, with 2 ml of the same buffer containing 1 ~I Na CI, into a Centric on-10 microconcentrator (Arnicon) containing 2 mg of ovalbumin (carrier) . The eluate was concentrated and diluted repeatedly with 50 mxt Tris-HCI (24% base), to remove salt. Aliquots of each purifica tion stage were examined by one-dimensional blotting with conjugate antibodies; the results (not shown) indicated that some disassembly of chains occurred during purification. Control and differentiated MEL cells , 108 of each type, were harvested after 100 h of growth , andlysed using a Dounce (above), in 2 ml of buffer containing: 20 mxt Tris-HCI (24% base), 1 rnxt EDTA , 2 rnxt dithiothreitol, 20 mxr NaCI, 0.1 rnxt phenylm ethylsulfonyl fluoride, 5 μg/ml leupeptin , and 10 μg/ml soybean trypsin inhibitor. Proteins soluble following centrifugation at 100,000 × g were fractionated by anion exchange chromatography as described (38.Pickart C.M. Graziani L.A. Dosch S.F. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1989; 272: 114-121Google Scholar), except that a Q-Sepharose column (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) was used . Fractions were collected into Centricon- 10 micro concentrators (Amicon), and exchanged into buffer (above) lacking NaCl. Each fraction was concentrated to 250 μl, and an 8-μl aliquot (3 x 106 cell equivalent) was assayed for the presence of 125I-ubiquitin thiol ester-forming species in the presence of MgATP and purified E1 (38.Pickart C.M. Graziani L.A. Dosch S.F. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1989; 272: 114-121Google Scholar). Autoradiographs were analyzed by densitometry (23.Pickart C.M. Vella A.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 12028-12035Google Scholar, 36.Pickart C.M. Summers R.G. Shim H. Kasperek E.M. Dev. Growth Differ. 1991; 33: 587-598Google Scholar). Preparation of total RNA, electrophoresis, and Northern blotting were carried out by established procedures (39.Chirgwin J.J. Przbyla A.E. MacDonald R.J. Rutter W. Biochemistry. 1979; 18: 5294-5299Google Scholar, 40.Ausubel F.A. Brent R. Kingston R.E. Moore D.D. Seidman J.G. Smith J.A. Struhl K. Current Protocols in Molecular Biology. John Wiley and Sons, New York1990Google Scholar). All hybridization steps were carried out at 65 °C. Blots were prehybridized (1 h ) in a solution containing: 5 x SSPE, 10 x Denhardt's, 100 μg/ml sheared salmon sperm DNA, 50% formamide , and 0.5% SDS. The blot was hybridized overnight with a 32P-labeled riboprobe corresponding to the 300 5ʹ- nucleotides of the bovine E2-25 K cDNA (106cpm/ml; gift of L. Mastrandrea, State University of New York at Buffalo). The blot was washed twice with 1 x SSPE, 0.5% SDS , and then once with 55% formamide, 2 x SS PE, 1% SDS. MEL cells are stably transformed with the Friend erythroleukemia virus (25.Friend C. Scher W. Holland J.G. Sato T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 1971; 68: 378-382Google Scholar). They are arrested at a proerythroblast-like stage, but becom committed to partial progression through the erythroid differentiation program following addition of Me2SO or other inducers to the medium. In vitro differentiation is marked by cessation of cell division, loss of the fibronect in receptor, changes in cytoskeletal proteins, induction of globin and the erythrocyte anion transporter (band 3), and a decrease in cell volume (2528). Under certain conditions, these changes may approach or equal what is seen in reticulocyte formation in vivo. Since highly differentiated MEL cells are fragile (28.Volloch V. Housman D. J. Cell Biol. 1982; 93: 390-394Google Scholar), we cultured cells, in suspension, in a BSA-containing medium that provides mechanical stabilization (26 - 28). Control cells grown in this way maintained log-phase growth for 4 days, while cells growing in the presence of Me2SO stopped dividing at ~72 h (data not shown). These growth properties are consistent with prior reports (27.Patel V.P. Lodish H.F. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 3105-3118Google Scholar, 41.GuptaRoy B. Cohen C.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 15326-15333Google Scholar). Band 3, an erythroid-specific protein, was first observed in differentiating cells at 72 h , and by 96 h reached the level seen in murine erythrocytes (Fig. 1A, lanes 1-4 versus 5-8). PAGE to monitor globin expression during differentiation . Globin protein was apparent in differentiating cells at ~72 h; by 96 h globin content was 43 ±11% of that in mature human erythrocytes, as determined by densitometry (n = 6; five independent experiments; Fig. 1B, lanes 5-8). As used here (and below), the term “content” refers to protein level normalized to cell number (i.e. mol or μg/cell). This method of normalization was used because cell number was easily determined with high accuracy. Changes in content are converted to changes in concentration by taking in to account changes in cell volume (below). A second feature of differentiated cells, usually apparent by 48h , was a decreased content of non-globin proteins (Fig. 1B, lanes 2-4 versus 6-8). To quantitate this effect, lanes 5 and 8 in Fig. 1B (and comparable lanes from other experiments) were scanned by densitometry. Peak areas were summed for all bands migrating more slowly than globin, and the results compared between lanes. The content of non-globin proteins in differentiated cells at 96h was - 60% of that in control cells (61±6%; n = 3; three experiments), but since there was a corresponding decrease in cell volume (below), the total concentration of non-globin proteins was comparable in control and differentiated cells. Overall, the data shown in Fig. 1 indicate that MEL cells grown in suspension in BSA-containing medium execute several aspects of the normal erythroid differentiation program, namely induced expression of erythroid-specific proteins (globin and band 3), and a reduction in the content of “progenitor” cell proteins. Similar results (data not shown) we

Lack of suitable amplification markers has hindered the use of the yeast system for investigating the mechanism of gene amplification in a eukaryote with a simple genome and well defined genetic system. Recently, methotrexate has been used to select for Saccharomyces cerevisiae mutants with de novo amplification of the dihydrofolate reductase gene (DFR1) (Huang, T. (1993) In Vivo Disruption and de Novo Amplification of the DFR1 Gene Encoding Dihydrofolate Reductase in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Ph. D. thesis, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada). We report here the detailed structure of a DFR1 episome amplified in methotrexate-resistant strain 25-1. The extrachromosomal DNA is found predominantly as a single 11-kilobase circular molecule. It consists of a 5.5-kilobase inverted duplication that contains the DFR1 locus and adjacent ARS (autonomously replicating sequence) element. This molecular configuration mimics the inferred structure of double minute chromosomes observed in a number of mammalian amplification systems and suggests that mechanisms that generate amplified DNAs are conserved from yeast to mammals.

Granulocyte macrophage-colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF) stimulates proliferation of various hematopoietic cells. Using cytoplasmic deletion mutants of the human GM-CSF receptor (hGMR) β subunit and tyrosine kinase inhibitors, we previously showed that distinct signaling pathways of hGMR are involved in the induction of c- fos/c- jun mRNAs and of c- myc mRNA/cell proliferation. We used polyoma virus (Py) replicon to analyze the initiation of DNA replication induced by hGM-CSF in mouse BA/F3 pro-B cells expressing hGMR. hGM-CSF efficiently stimulated Py replication in the presence of Py enhancer and Py large T antigen supplied in trans. Analyses of Py enhancer mutants revealed that hGM-CSF promoted Py replication and activated transcription of the Py early promoter through the PEA3/PEBP5 region of Py enhancer. The membrane proximal region of hGMR β subunit is required for activation of PEA3/PEBP5-dependent replication which is also required for activation of DNA synthesis in the host cells. In contrast, a more distal region which is essential for activation of c- fos and c- jun genes is required for the PEA3/PEBP5-dependent transcription of Py early promoter. These results indicate that distinct signaling pathways of hGMR are required to activate PEA3/PEBP5-dependent replication and transcription although the same enhancer is required for both activities. Using cytoplasmic deletion mutants of the human GM-CSF receptor (hGMR) β subunit and tyrosine kinase inhibitors, we previously showed that distinct signaling pathways of hGMR are involved in the induction of c- fos/c- jun mRNAs and of c- myc mRNA/cell proliferation. We used polyoma virus (Py) replicon to analyze the initiation of DNA replication induced by hGM-CSF in mouse BA/F3 pro-B cells expressing hGMR. hGM-CSF efficiently stimulated Py replication in the presence of Py enhancer and Py large T antigen supplied in trans. Analyses of Py enhancer mutants revealed that hGM-CSF promoted Py replication and activated transcription of the Py early promoter through the PEA3/PEBP5 region of Py enhancer. The membrane proximal region of hGMR β subunit is required for activation of PEA3/PEBP5-dependent replication which is also required for activation of DNA synthesis in the host cells. In contrast, a more distal region which is essential for activation of c- fos and c- jun genes is required for the PEA3/PEBP5-dependent transcription of Py early promoter. These results indicate that distinct signaling pathways of hGMR are required to activate PEA3/PEBP5-dependent replication and transcription although the same enhancer is required for both activities. Granulocyte macrophage-colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF)1 1The abbreviations used are: GM-CSFgranulocyte macrophage-colony stimulating factorILinterleukinmILmouse interleukinhGMRhuman GM-CSF receptorntnucleotide(s)CATchloramphenicol acetyltransferaseRSVRous sarcoma virusEMSAelectrophoretic mobility shift assayPypolyoma virusLTaglarge T antigenCBFcore binding factor. induces early responsive genes and promotes proliferation in various hematopoietic cells (1Miyajima A. Kitamura T. Harada N. Yokota T. Arai K. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1992; 10: 295-331Google Scholar, 2Watanabe S. Nakayama N. Yokota T. Miyajima A. Arai K. Curr. Opin. Biotechnol. 1991; 2: 227-237Google Scholar). Interleukin-3 (IL-3) elicits similar, if not identical, activities. High affinity GM-CSF receptor (GMR) and IL-3 receptor consist of the α subunit specific to each and of a common β subunit. Although this high affinity GMR is mainly expressed in hematopoietic cells, reconstituted hGMR in fibroblasts transduces signals to activate early response genes and cell proliferation (3Watanabe S. Muto A. Mui A.-F. Miyajima A. Arai K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 1440-1448Google Scholar). This means that hGMR can be linked to signal transduction pathways in fibroblasts and molecules specific to hematopoietic cells are not required to transduce these signals. Signal transducing molecules such as ras, raf, and microtubule-associated protein kinase required for the induction of c -fos mRNA linked with various growth factor receptors carrying tyrosine kinase activity have been extensively studied in fibroblast systems. These molecules are also involved in the GM-CSF/IL-3 signaling pathway for the induction of c- fos mRNA in hematopoietic cells (4Carroll M.P. Clark-Lewis I. Rapp U.R. May W.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 19812-19817Google Scholar, 5Satoh T. Uehara Y. Kaziro Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 2537-2541Google Scholar). granulocyte macrophage-colony stimulating factor interleukin mouse interleukin human GM-CSF receptor nucleotide(s) chloramphenicol acetyltransferase Rous sarcoma virus electrophoretic mobility shift assay polyoma virus large T antigen core binding factor. Analyses of hGMR β mutants carrying deletion from the cytoplasmic tail (C terminus) revealed that the region covering amino acid position up to 763 is required to activate c- fos and c- jun genes. In contrast, the region more proximal to membrane covering amino acid position up to 544 is required for activation of c- myc gene and proliferation (6Watanabe S. Muto A. Yokota T. Miyajima A. Arai K. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1993; 4: 983-992Google Scholar, 7Sato N. Sakamaki K. Terada N. Arai K. Miyajima A. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 4181-4189Google Scholar). Furthermore, IL-3/GM-CSF induced c- fos and c- jun activation is insensitive to tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as herbimycin or genistein, whereas proliferation is completely suppressed by these reagents (6Watanabe S. Muto A. Yokota T. Miyajima A. Arai K. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1993; 4: 983-992Google Scholar). This indicates that the signaling pathway leading to DNA replication and activation of the c- myc gene is likely to be independent of the signaling pathway for the induction of c- fos/c- jun mRNAs. In contrast to the well characterized signaling pathway for activation of the c- fos gene, less is known of signaling mechanisms for cell proliferation and activation of the c- myc gene in mammalian cells. In yeast systems, characterization of cell cycle mutants led to identification of key molecules such as cdc2/28 or cyclin required for G1/to S phase transition (8Forsburg S.L. Nurse P. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1991; 7: 227-256Google Scholar). Subsequently, mammalian homologues of these kinases and cyclins were identified and their roles in regulation of cell cycle have been closely examined (9Matsushime H. Roussel M.F. Ashmun R.A. Sherr C.J. Cell. 1991; 65: 701-713Google Scholar, 10Koff A. Giordano A. Desai D. Yamashita K. Harper J.W. Elledge S. Nishimoto T. Morgan D.O. Franza B.R. Roberts J.M. Science. 1992; 257: 1689-1694Google Scholar). While cell cycle regulators such as cyclin-dependent kinase/cyclins and anti-oncogene such as retinoblastoma or p53 are regulated by growth factors including IL-3/GM-CSF (11Ando D. Ajchenbaum-Cymbalista F. Griffin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 9571-9575Google Scholar, 12Borellini F. Glazer R.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 7923-7928Google Scholar), the mechanisms by which these molecules regulate transition of G1to S phase remain unanswered. It should also be noted that the mechanism of initiation of DNA replication of mammalian chromosomes is largely unknown. Analyses of the regulation of initiation of chromosomal DNA replication by growth factors have been hampered because an appropriate assay for DNA replication of host cells has not been available. Protocols for assaying cell proliferation generally make use of incorporation into DNA of nucleotide substrates or analogues, or binding of drugs to DNA, none of these approaches provide direct information regarding the initiation of DNA replication. For example, the incorporation of radioactive thymidine does not distinguish initiation and elongation steps of replicative DNA synthesis. In addition, despite extensive efforts to characterize the nature of chromosomal origins of DNA replication, the results are inconclusive and even the presence of a specific replication origin is controversial (13DePamphilis M.L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1993; 62: 29-63Google Scholar). Replication systems which make use of defined DNA templates such as small phages and plasmids provided excellent models to study DNA replication in bacteria (14Kornberg A. Baker T.A. DNA Replication. W. H. Freeman and Co., New York1992Google Scholar). Likewise, virus systems offer many advantages for studying mammalian DNA replication (13DePamphilis M.L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1993; 62: 29-63Google Scholar, 15Challberg M.D. Kelly T.J. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1989; 58: 671-717Google Scholar). The mechanisms of replication of SV40 and polyoma virus (Py), the closely related double stranded circular DNA virus, have been extensively studied in fibroblasts (14Kornberg A. Baker T.A. DNA Replication. W. H. Freeman and Co., New York1992Google Scholar). Several features of SV40 and Py make them attractive models to study chromosomal replication (15Challberg M.D. Kelly T.J. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1989; 58: 671-717Google Scholar). In both systems, except for the large T antigen (LTag), all of the factors required for execution of replication are present in the host cells (15Challberg M.D. Kelly T.J. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1989; 58: 671-717Google Scholar). Second, Py or SV40 replication is host cell cycle dependent (16D'Urso G. Marraccino R.L. Marshak D.R. Roberts J.M. Science. 1990; 250: 786-791Google Scholar). The Py system in particular is very useful, where Py LTag does not cause tumorigenic transformation even though it induces immortality, and middle Tag is mainly involved in transformation of the host cell. (17Rassoulzadegan M. Naghashfar Z. Cowie A. Carr A. Grisoni M. Kamen R. Cuzin F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1983; 80: 4354-4358Google Scholar). Another interesting feature of Py replicon is enhancer dependence of Py replication (13DePamphilis M.L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1993; 62: 29-63Google Scholar). There are several observations that implicate involvement of transcription factor/enhancer for eukaryote chromosomal DNA replication. Py may be a good model to elucidate the role of enhancer in DNA replication (18Fangman W.L. Brewer B.J. Cell. 1992; 71: 363-366Google Scholar, 19Dutta A. Curr. Biol. 1993; 3: 709-712Google Scholar). Origin of Py consists of two elements, the origin core and the enhancer. The core contains a palindrome that includes two repeats of the LTag recognition pentanucleotide sequence motif and A/T-rich sequence. The enhancer sequence in the Py genome is essential for Py replication (20Tyndall C. La Mantia G. Thacker C.M. Favaloro J. Kamen R. Nucleic Acids Res. 1981; 9: 6231-6250Google Scholar), and is replaceable with cellular, viral, and yeast enhancers (21De Villiers J. Schaffner W. Tyndall C. Lupton S. Kamen R. Nature. 1984; 312: 242-246Google Scholar, 22Baru M. Shlissel M. Manor H. J. Virol. 1991; 65: 3496-3503Google Scholar, 23Bennett-Cook E.R. Hassell J.A. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 959-969Google Scholar). Cell type specificity of Py replication is likely to be defined by the enhancer, because mutation or replacement of the enhancer region allow Py to replicate in types of cells different from the original (21De Villiers J. Schaffner W. Tyndall C. Lupton S. Kamen R. Nature. 1984; 312: 242-246Google Scholar, 24Herbomel P. Bourachot B. Yaniv M. Cell. 1984; 39: 653-662Google Scholar, 25Fujimura F.K. Deininger P.L. Friedmann T. Linney E. Cell. 1981; 23: 809-814Google Scholar, 26Campbell B.A. Villarreal L.P. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1986; 6: 2068-2079Google Scholar). Py replicon has been studied almost exclusively in mouse fibroblasts either transformed or in the presence of fetal calf serum. However, the requirement of growth factors or cytokines for Py replication has remained to be determined. Based on our finding that hGMR is functional in both hematopoietic cells and fibroblasts, we asked whether Py could serve as a model replicon to examine the initiation of DNA replication induced by IL-3/GM-CSF in hematopoietic cells. We obtained evidence that hGM-CSF induces Py replication in BA/F3 cells expressing hGMR. The region of the β subunit of hGMR required for Py replication is indistinguishable from that required for cell proliferation. Fetal calf serum was from Biocell laboratories Co. Ltd. Gene (Amst.). 1987; 58: 273-281Google Scholar). [α-32P]CTP, [α-32P]GTP, and [3H]acetylcoenzyme A were from Amersham Japan Co. Ltd. Genistein was from Wako Pure Chemicals. Cell. 1985; 41: 727-734Google Scholar) was maintained in RPMI 1640 medium containing 10% fetal calf serum, 1 ng/ml mIL-3, 100 units/ml penicillin, and 100 μg/ml streptomycin. Transfected BA/F3 cells expressing hGMR α and β subunits (BA/FGMR) were grown in the same type of media but supplemented with 500 μg/ml G418. pPyOICAT contains the Py fragment (nt 5267-nt 152) which includes replication origin core sequence (nt 5267-nt 56) and early gene promoter but lacks enhancer region, and chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) coding sequence (29Murakami Y. Asano M. Satake M. Ito Y. Oncogene. 1990; 5: 5-13Google Scholar, 30Murakami Y. Satake M. Yamaguchi-Iwai Y. Sakai M. Muramatsu M. Ito Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 3947-3951Google Scholar). Synthetic oligonucleotides or Py enhancer fragments were inserted at the BglII site of pPyOICAT for each plasmid. For pPyBPPCAT and pPyWACAT, the region from BclI site (nt 5021) to PvuII site (nt 5265) and A core (nt 5017-nt 5130) of Py enhancer was inserted, respectively, at the BglII site of pPyOICAT. The other inserted fragments are schematically shown in Fig. 3 A. pPyBPPΔCAT is an origin defective control plasmid with BPP fragment as an enhancer, lacking 4 base pairs (nt 5-nt 8) in the Py LTag binding site of the origin core. pRSVLTag is the expression plasmid, and contains the Py LTag coding region under the control of RSV-long terminal repeat. DNA replication of transfected plasmid was assayed by DpnI analysis (29Murakami Y. Asano M. Satake M. Ito Y. Oncogene. 1990; 5: 5-13Google Scholar). Plasmids were introduced into semiconfluent BA/F3 cells (1.2 × 106cells/sample) by the DEAE-dextran method as described elsewhere (3Watanabe S. Muto A. Mui A.-F. Miyajima A. Arai K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 1440-1448Google Scholar). Cells resuspended in factor-depleted media were incubated for 5 h and then stimulated with 5 ng/ml mIL-3, hGM-CSF, or mIL-4. After incubation for an additional 24 h, cells were harvested and washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline. Low molecular weight DNA was isolated by the Hirt extraction method (31Hirt B. J. Mol. Biol. 1967; 26: 365-369Google Scholar). Briefly, cells were resuspended in 1 ml of Hirt solution (10% SDS, 10 m M Tris, pH 7.8, 10 m M EDTA) and lysed by incubation for 5 min at room temperature. Then, 250 μl of 5 M NaCl was added and mixed by tumbling. After an overnight incubation at 4°C, the extract was centrifuged for 60 min by a microcentrifuge. Supernatant was extracted twice with phenol/chloroform, and DNA was ethanol precipitated and resuspended in 20 μl of 10 m M Tris, pH 7.4, 1 m M EDTA. In separate experiments, radiolabeled plasmid DNA was used as an internal marker to determine the recovery of the low molecular weight DNA. Ten μl of DNA solution was digested with HindIII, that linearizes template plasmid, and DpnI. As DpnI digests only methylated or hemimethylated recognition sites of DNA, newly synthesized DNA is resistant to DpnI digestion. DNA were electrophoretically separated in a 0.8% agarose gel, and transferred to Hybond-N+ (Amersham) by alkaline blotting (32Reed K.C. Mann D.A. Nucleic Acids Res. 1985; 13: 7207-7221Google Scholar). DNA blots were hybridized with denatured HindIII-digested pPyOICAT DNA labeled with 32P by the random priming kit (U. S. Biochemical Corp., Cleveland, OH) using QuikHyb rapid hybridization solution (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) and according to the manufacturer's instructions. Blots were washed and exposed to an imaging plate for 15 min and intensity of bands was quantified using a FUJI Image Analyzer (Model BAS-2000). CAT activities were analyzed by diffusion analysis (33Maniatis T. Fritsch E.F. Sambrook J. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1982Google Scholar). Briefly, BA/F3 cells were co-transfected with 10 μg of template DNA and 2 μg each of hGMR α and β subunits plasmids (3Watanabe S. Muto A. Mui A.-F. Miyajima A. Arai K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 1440-1448Google Scholar) by the DEAE-dextran method and cultured overnight with complete media. Cells were depleted of mIL-3 for 5 h, and restimulated with 5 ng/ml of either mIL-3 or hGM-CSF. After a 12-h incubation, cells were harvested and lysed in 50 μl of 0.25 M Tris, pH 7.4, by three cycles of freezing and thawing. Each sample containing approximately 50 μg of total protein was subjected to CAT activity. BA/F3 cells expressing various truncated β subunit mutants and the wild type α subunit (5 × 106) were depleted of mIL-3 for 5 h and stimulated with hGM-CSF or mIL-3. After incubation for 3 h, these cells were collected and nuclear proteins were extracted as described elsewhere (6Watanabe S. Muto A. Yokota T. Miyajima A. Arai K. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1993; 4: 983-992Google Scholar, 34Watanabe S. Yssel H. Harada Y. Arai K. Int. Immunol. 1994; 6: 523-532Google Scholar). EMSA was made with nuclear extracts prepared from BA/F3 cells, according to the method described above. PEA3/PEBP5 (5′-CGCAGGAAGTGACGG-5′) oligonucleotide was chemically synthesized and purified by Sephadex G-50 nick columns (Pharmacia, Upsala, Sweden) after being labeled with [α-32P]dGTP. The extracts containing 5 μg of protein were incubated with a labeled probe for 15 min at room temperature in a total volume of 15 μl containing 10 m M Tris, pH 7.5, 50 m M KCl, 1 m M dithiothreitol, 1 m M EDTA, pH 8.0, 12.5% glycerol, 0.1% Triton X-100, 5 μg of bovine serum albumin, and 0.5 μg of poly(dI-dC) as a nonspecific competitor. The DNA-protein complexes were electrophoresed on a 4% polyacrylamide gel in 6.7 m M Tris, pH 7.5, 3.3 m M sodium acetate, and 1 m M EDTA, pH 8.0. Then the gel was transferred to Whatman 3MM paper, dried, and analyzed by the FUJI Image Analyzer (model BAS-2000). To determine whether or not IL-3 or GM-CSF induces the replication of Py, we analyzed the replication of transiently transfected plasmid pPyBPPCAT that contains the Py origin region, including the transcription initiation site with the entire Py enhancer BPP region (29Murakami Y. Asano M. Satake M. Ito Y. Oncogene. 1990; 5: 5-13Google Scholar). The DNA template and pRSV-LTag, the expression plasmid supplying Py LTag in trans, were transfected using the DEAE-dextran method into BA/FGMR (6Watanabe S. Muto A. Yokota T. Miyajima A. Arai K. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1993; 4: 983-992Google Scholar, 35Sakamaki K. Miyajima I. Kitamura T. Miyajima A. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 3541-3550Google Scholar). This cell line extensively proliferates in response to mIL-3 or hGM-CSF and only transiently (up to 48 h) survives in the presence of mIL-4. Transfected cells were incubated without mIL-3 for 5 h and stimulated with mIL-3, hGM-CSF, or mIL-4. After a 24-h incubation, these cells were harvested and small molecular weight DNAs were extracted by the Hirt extraction method as described under “Materials and Methods.” DNAs were digested with DpnI which cleaves only unreplicated DNA. As shown in Fig. 1, mIL-3 and hGM-CSF but not mIL-4 induced replication of pPyBPPCAT. pPyBPPΔoriCAT, which lacks 4-base pair nucleotides (nt 5-nt 8) within the origin region and is unable to replicate in COP5 cells stably expressing Py LTag (29Murakami Y. Asano M. Satake M. Ito Y. Oncogene. 1990; 5: 5-13Google Scholar), did not replicate with either stimulation. These results demonstrated that mIL-3 or hGM-CSF stimulated Py origin-dependent replication in BA/FGMR cells. The lack of Py replication by mIL-4 may be consistent with the observation that mIL-4 supports the survival but not the proliferation of BA/F3 cells. Py LTag is a multifunctional protein essential for Py replication and regulation of Py early and late transcription (36Cogen G. Virology. 1978; 85: 222-230Google Scholar, 37Farmerie W.G. Folk W.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1984; 68: 6919-6923Google Scholar). We next examined the dependence of mIL-3- or hGM-CSF-induced Py replication on Py LTag. BA/FGMR cells (5 × 106cells) were cotransfected with various amounts of pRSV-LTag DNA and 1 μg of pPyBPPoriCATand replication of the latter plasmid was analyzed as described above. As expected, Py replication was completely dependent on the presence of Py LTag (Fig. 2). pPyBPPoriCAT did not replicate in the absence of the LTag plasmid and the extent of replication was proportional to the amount of pRSV-LTag DNA cotransfected. In the following experiments, pRSV-LTag DNA, about 20-fold excess amount of template DNA containing Py replication origin, was used. The Py enhancer BPP contains two core elements, A and B. The A element has been shown to respond to external growth factor stimuli (38Yamaguchi Y. Satake M. Ito Y. J. Virol. 1989; 63: 1040-1048Google Scholar) and has been extensively characterized. The A element contains binding sites for at least three transcription activators, PEA1/PEBP1 (AP-1 consensus), PEA2/PEBP2, and PEA3/PEBP5 (ets family consensus). Transcription factors shown to interact with these binding motifs are AP-1, PEBP2 (39Ogawa E. Maruyama M. Kagoshima H. Inuzuka M. Lu J. Satake M. Shigesada K. Ito Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 6859-6863Google Scholar) /CBF (core binding factor) (40Wang S. Wang Q. Crute B.E. Melnikova I.N. Keller S.R. Speck N.A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 3324-3339Google Scholar), and PEBP3 (41Xin J. Cowie A. Lachance P. Hassell J.A. Genes & Dev. 1992; 6: 481-496Google Scholar) /PEA3-91 (42Martin M.E. Yang X.Y. Folk W.R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1992; 12: 2213-2221Google Scholar) /PEBP5 (43Cegielskaa A. Virshup D.M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 1202-1211Google Scholar), respectively. To delineate DNA elements in Py enhancer responsible for mIL-3- or hGM-CSF-dependent replication, we employed various plasmids containing mutations in A element (30Murakami Y. Satake M. Yamaguchi-Iwai Y. Sakai M. Muramatsu M. Ito Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 3947-3951Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 3 A, A element, either the wild type or the mutant carrying various point mutations, was inserted at the BglII site of the pPyOICAT plasmid. These plasmids were cotransfected with pRSV-LTag into BA/FGMR cells and replication of plasmid induced by either mIL-3 or hGM-CSF was analyzed. Transfection efficiency of each sample as judged by luciferase activity of cotransfected SRα-luciferase plasmid was nearly the same. pPyWACAT carrying the wild type A element replicate in response to mIL-3 (Fig. 3 B). pPyM3ACAT carrying two point mutations at the PEA3/PEBP5 site (ets site) failed to replicate in response to mIL-3, indicating that this site is essential for mIL-3-dependent Py replication. In contrast, pPyM1ACAT carrying two point mutations at the PEA1/PEBP1 site (AP-1 site) showed only a slight decrease in replication (Fig. 3 B), and pPyM2ACAT carrying two point mutations at the PEA2/PEBP2 site (CBF site) elicited a significantly reduced replicative activity. The relative level of replicated pPyCAT DNA plasmids were presented in Fig. 3 A. These results suggest that the AP-1 site, only slightly, and PEBP2/CBF site, to much greater degree, contribute to mIL-3-dependent Py replication. Essentially the same results were obtained with hGM-CSF stimulation (data not shown). To further confirm this finding, we next analyzed a series of plasmids that contain subfragments of either the wild type or the mutant A element in tandem and inserted at the BglII site of the pPyOICAT plasmid (Fig. 3 A). As expected, pPyALCAT containing six tandem repeats of the ets binding site replicated efficiently in response to mIL-3, and pPyAECAT containing six tandem repeats of the PEA2/PEBP2/CBF site replicated at a much lower level than pPyALCAT. pPyAMCAT, carrying six tandem repeats of the AP-1 site, showed almost no replicative activity in response to mIL-3 (Fig. 3 B). Essentially the same results were obtained with hGM-CSF stimulation. Taken together, these results show that the contribution to mIL-3 or hGM-CSF-induced Py replication is most prominent with the ets binding site, much less with the PEBP2/CBF site, and negligible with the AP-1 site. We previously showed that the cytoplasmic regions of hGMR β subunit required for induction of c- fos/c- jun mRNAs and c- myc mRNA induction/cell proliferation differ (6Watanabe S. Muto A. Yokota T. Miyajima A. Arai K. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1993; 4: 983-992Google Scholar, 7Sato N. Sakamaki K. Terada N. Arai K. Miyajima A. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 4181-4189Google Scholar). Mutant 544 carrying a deletion from the C terminus to amino acid position 544 is fully active, whereas mutant 517 is weakly active, and mutant 455 is completely inactive to induce c- myc mRNA induction/cell proliferation (6Watanabe S. Muto A. Yokota T. Miyajima A. Arai K. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1993; 4: 983-992Google Scholar). To determine whether or not the same region of hGMR β subunit is required for hGM-CSF-induced Py replication, we used BA/F3 cells expressing hGMR composed of the wild type α subunit and mutant β subunit carrying a series of C terminus deletions (BA/F3GMRβ mutants) (35Sakamaki K. Miyajima I. Kitamura T. Miyajima A. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 3541-3550Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 4, mutant 544 is fully active as the original β subunit, whereas mutant 517 is active but has a much reduced ability to support pPyWACAT replication. As expected, mutant 455 which lacks the potential to support proliferation of the host cells, failed to promote pPyWACAT replication. When pPyALCAT was used as the template, the requirement of hGMR β subunit for replication was stricter and mutant 517 had lost the potential to support replication of this Py construct. These results are in good agreement with the findings of host chromosome replication monitored by thymidine incorporation, i.e. mutant 544 was fully active but mutants 517 and 455 were inactive in response to hGM-CSF (6Watanabe S. Muto A. Yokota T. Miyajima A. Arai K. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1993; 4: 983-992Google Scholar). Using CAT gene as the reporter, we then examined whether or not mIL-3 or hGM-CSF would stimulate transcription through PEA3/PEBP5, the ets binding site of Py enhancer in the absence of pRSV-LTag. BA/F3 cells transiently transfected with 10-μg derivatives of pPyOICAT containing various enhancer elements and 2 μg each of hGMR α and β subunits plasmids (3Watanabe S. Muto A. Mui A.-F. Miyajima A. Arai K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 1440-1448Google Scholar) were depleted of mIL-3 for 5 h and were re-stimulated with 5 ng of either mIL-3 or hGM-CSF. Cells were harvested after a 12-h incubation, as described under “Materials and Methods.” IL-3 induced fold induction of each construct in BA/F3 cells is shown in Fig. 5 A. Transcription (%) activities normalized using the value of pPyWACAT are summarized in the right column of each construct (Fig. 3 A). Essentially the same results were obtained by hGM-CSF stimulation. mIL-3- or hGM-CSF-induced CAT activity of pPyWACAT and this activity was lost by introduction of mutations in the PEA3/PEBP5 site (pPyM3ACAT). Mutations in either the PEA1/PEBP1 site (pPyM1ACAT) or PEA2/PEBP2 site (pPyM2ACAT) reduced CAT activities to some extent but not completely. CAT activity of pPyALCAT induced by mIL-3 or hGM-CSF was more than 10 times stronger than that of pPyWACAT. This may be caused by pPyALCAT containing 6 tandem copies of the PEA3/PEBP5 site. pPyALMCAT that contains point mutations in the AL region lost the potential to respond to mIL-3 or hGM-CSF. These results indicated that PEA3/PEBP5 is also functional as an enhancer responding to mIL-3 or hGM-CSF signals. Weak activity of pPyWACAT suggests that the PEA3/PEBP5 site in single copy is insufficient for activation or that other regions affect the PEA3/PEBP5 region in a negative manner. We then analyzed the ability of hGMR β mutants to induce CAT activity of pPyALCAT in response to hGM-CSF by cotransfection of various GMR β mutants plasmids (35Sakamaki K. Miyajima I. Kitamura T. Miyajima A. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 3541-3550Google Scholar) and reporter plasmid pPyALCAT (Fig. 5 B). hGM-CSF stimulated CAT activity through mutant 826 (data not shown) and mutant 763 in response to hGM-CSF at levels similar to the wild type construct. In contrast, mutants 626 and 544 failed to transduce signals to induce CAT activity of pPyALCAT even though these mutant receptors can induce replication of the same Py construct in response to hGM-CSF. As expected, mutants 517 and 455 did not activate CAT activity or the replication of pPyALCAT. Essentially the same results were obtained with BA/F3GMRβ mutants cells (data not shown). Thus, the region between positions 455 and 517 of the hGMR β subunit is required for the replication induced by hGM-CSF, and that between positions 763 and 626 is required for the transcriptional activation of pPyALCAT.
